Indeed, it was blamed when an estimated two hundred thousand snaps were hacked in 2014 and allegedly ended up on the dark web

container-title: Smith, "The Use of Electronics in the Observation and Control of Human Behavior and Its Possible Use in Rehabilitation and Parole," Issues in Criminology 7
title: Although tagging or inserting tracking devices into humans has never been widely accepted, there are a few exceptions. There is the long and troubling history of marking some humans (those who have been enslaved) with brands or tattoos. And in the 1970s, the U.S. criminal justice system started to use electronic tracking devices to monitor individuals on parole. This form of tagging has frequently been welcomed (even by many prison reformers) as a progressive alternative to extended prison sentences, rather than viewed as an infringement of privacy
